results.description:
**This is a Multi-Group Event so you will be meeting all sorts of interesting new friends at this event led by Event Host Tim ***


Virtually every important postwar art trend matriculated below Manhattan's 14th St. 

The Abstract Expressionists and the New York School, the nascent Soho and use of repurposed industrial spaces as studio and gallery for Pop artists, performance and site-specific installations, the East Village graffiti galleries and Edward Hopper's Nighthawks - arguably the most famous American painting of them all - all happened within walking distance of each other.

Fred W. McDarrah, the longtime Village Voice photographer and picture editor, was right there with his camera as it happened. His iconic art world photos are the basis for a new walking tour.

See where Robert Rauschenberg inadvertently started the sushi craze in New York City over 40 years ago. What other tour can offer you that!?

While McDarrah's 250,000-image archive is an encyclopedic catalog of the people, places, movements, trends and events of the New York scene over the second half of the 20th century, his collection of photographs of artists is truly unique and often the sole visual record of a special time and place in the history of American art.

Every ticket on every tour includes a keepsake postcard packet of iconic McDarrah images and the tours go to the same locations to see how they have changed,  how they are the same, and to hear the stories behind the famous photos.

The Artist's World tour is based on a 2015 exhibition at Chelsea's Steven Kasher Gallery that featured vintage photos from McDarrah's seminal 1961 book

Click below to buy tickets and enter Promo Code MCDTOUR for 50% off!!! 


****CLICK HERE TO BOOK TOUR****

(Pictured Above: Andy Warhol)

Photo © 2015 Estate of Fred W. McDarrah  All Rights Reserved

results.description:
Join us on December 19th at for two hours packed full of networking, masterminding, connection & sharing with other dynamic female entrepreneurs, like yourself! Hosted by Tracy Robin of Shine Yoga Center and Sam Popp of Teach + Learn Networking, leave with fresh inspiration & a new community to support you in your entrepreneurial journey.


A complete agenda and list of sponsors will be released soon!

Please note: This is an event for women only.

Who is Sam Popp?

Sam Popp is the founder and owner of Teach + Learn Networking, an event and content platform for entrepreneurs and business owners. Drawing on a diverse background of social work and sales, Sam curates events and leads workshops with one focus in mind: professional relationship building can be easy (and fun!) once given the right tools. Sam is Jersey born and raised, but now lives in Manhattan.

Who is Tracy Robin?

Tracy Robin is a Certified Life Coach & Business Mentor for entrepreneurs, an ERYT500, a Certified Kripalu Yoga Teacher, the co-owner & founder of Shine Yoga Center in Cliffside Park, New Jersey and the director of Shine Yoga Center’s Yoga Teacher Certification Program. She coaches clients globally and travels nationally & internationally leading classes, workshops & retreats. 

Who can attend?

Women Entrepreneurs and women starting or transitioning into their own biz - who are passionate about personal & professional development, and who want connect and be in community with other dynamic women in business.

What should I bring?

Business cards, a friend if you'd like, an open mind

How much does it cost?

$5 online and $10 at the door. Enjoy yummy cookies and giveaways from our sponsors. RSVP and we'll see you there!

Want to be the first to know about our upcoming events & gatherings? Interested in doing a giveaway or sponsoring our next event? Contact Sam Popp at [masked] for more information.

This event is being held in partnership with Holistic Women Entrepreneurs of NJ and NYC.

results.description:
Join us on December 19th for two hours packed full of networking, masterminding, connection & sharing with other dynamic female entrepreneurs, like yourself! We'll be talking about events, strategic alliances, social media and other marketing keys that will help build your know-like-trust factor and have your list growing for you with ease. 


BUY TICKETS HERE


No one told us when we became entrepreneurs that it meant we were going into sales. But the truth is, if you don't make sales, you don't have a business.  And furthermore, if you don't have clients, then you have no sales.  


Finding clients is one of the biggest challenges for women entrepreneurs. We don't know where to find them, and we are not sure how many we need and we  are are afraid to come off as pushy and salesy and sleazy.

BUY TICKETS HERE 

All of that becomes easier when you 

1. Are authentic with your message and you know your ideal client and the market you are speaking to AND

2. Have list building techniques that will help your business take off and position you as the go to expert in your field.  

Hosted by Tracy Robin of Shine Yoga Center and Sam Popp of Teach + Learn Networking, leave with fresh inspiration & a new community to support you in your entrepreneurial journey.


BUY TICKETS HERE

Our Sponsor: 

Delicious Vegan Chocolate Chip Cookies provided by Hanina Osborn. 

Hanina Osborn is a vegan mamma who loves running, hiking, baking, and essential oils. She thoroughly enjoys working from home so that she can spend more time with her two awesome little boys and her amazing and supportive husband.  Hanina strives to live a healthy lifestyle which is why she chose to turn her passion for essential oils into a business that she can run from home. At heart she is a teacher so she loves educating others by running fun classes on the power of natural healthcare. Other than teaching and essential oils, Hanina’s passion is vegan baking. From cookies to muffins to cakes and even specialty cakes, you name it, she loves making it.

Plus two surprise giveaways from Tracy & Sam.

Who is Tracy Robin?

Tracy Robin is a Certified Life Coach & Business Mentor for entrepreneurs, an ERYT500, a Certified Kripalu Yoga Teacher, the co-owner & founder of Shine Yoga Center in Cliffside Park, New Jersey and the director of Shine Yoga Center’s Yoga Teacher Certification Program. An entrepreneur & business owner since 2000, she coaches clients globally and travels nationally & internationally leading classes, workshops & retreats. 


Who is Sam Popp?


Sam Popp is the founder and owner of Teach + Learn Networking, an event and content platform for entrepreneurs and business owners in NJ and NYC. Drawing on a diverse background of social work and sales, Sam curates events and leads workshops with one focus in mind: professional relationship building can be easy (and fun!) once given the right tools. Sam is Jersey born and raised, but now lives in Manhattan.

Women Entrepreneurs and women starting or transitioning into their own biz - who are passionate about personal & professional development, and who want connect and be in community with other dynamic women in business.

Business cards, a friend if you'd like, an open mind

BUY TICKETS HERE

results.description:
HELLOOOOO BROOKLYN! Our last Amazing Scavenger Museum Hunt in BK was a big hit so we're doing it again! 

This is an INDOOR hunt and includes admission to the Brooklyn Museum. You will receive a series of clues and perform mental and physical (nothing too strenuous) challenges along the way. 

It is a great way to connect with friends or meet new ones. You can sign up as a team (2-4 members) or as an individual and we will partner you with a team. Each member of the winning team receives a gift package.

GET TICKETS HERE - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Dec-19-2015_at_1230PM

What to expect: 


• Admission to the Brooklyn Museum

• A fun day with with new friends 

• Mental and physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

PREPAY ONLY EVENT (No tickets sold at door)  

*Tickets $35-$40 depending upon when you purchase - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Dec-19-2015_at_1230PM

*We only have a limited # of tix available. Ticket price will go up as event gets closer so get yours ASAP.

Who can attend? All are welcome. This is not an age/ethnic/gender specific event. 


What should I wear? Dress comfortable – Most teams wear sneakers.


What should I bring? A fun attitude, a smart phone if you have (fully charged). The hunt is run through an app called ScanQuest.  You can download that before you come.

Where do we go? There’s no set course. Find your own way. It’s a ‘choose your own adventure hunt. 

What if it rains? No problem, the scavenger hunt is all indoors.

How many people will be attending? This is a multi-Meetup event and we have over 20 groups co-organizing it. We expect up to 50 members to attend.

Where do I get a ticket? You must prepay here to attend. Tickets will not be sold at the door. We expect this event to sell out so please get your tickets ASAP here - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkmuseum/dates/Dec-19-2015_at_1230PM
results.name: The Amazing Museum Scavenger Hunt (includes entry to BKLYN Museum) PREPAY ONLY

Waiting List: The day before an event we tend to have a lot of people drop out so do not be discouraged if you're on the waiting list--there's a good chance you'll be able to join.


Attending List: Please remember that the RSVP list closes at 5pm the day before an event. If you change your RSVP to NO after that time or are a no-show, someone on the waiting list could be left out. We take that very seriously.

Club Hours: C&B sets aside space for us from 12:30pm to 2:30pm so those are the official club hours. Everyone is free to stay longer if they wish.

First-Timers: If it is your first time at C&B, you will have to take a lesson from the range staff. If you are an experienced archer, you must at least stay for the safety portion (no exceptions, range rules). Lessons start at half past the hour so if you miss the 12:30pm, you may have to sit around and wait for the 1:30pm. Please be on time.

Public Transportation: LIRR to Hicksville and then a taxi from the station to C&B (make sure to tell them 11 Commercial St in Hicksville). The train from Penn gets into Hicksville at 11:55 am. The cab rate as of 1/1/14 is $6.50 +$2 for each additional person. Those of you taking the train may wish to post a message to the group to share a cab.

Range Costs: Make sure to mention when you pay for range time you are shooting with the NYC Archery Group to get the CLUB ONLY rates:

$7.00 for the first hour, $5 each additional hour OR $15 to shoot all day
$1.00 for a target
$11 per hour for a rental bow and arrows
$5.00 for a lesson (includes first hour)

Visit the C&B website for the most up-to-date information.

See you on the shooting line!

results.name: Meet up and play some afternoon soccer

results.description:
Compassion is the fashion, and fur is DEAD! the "peace on earth" winter holiday draweth nigh, and as such, Caring Activists Against Fur (CAAF), will be making our immutable opposition to the horrific Chinese fur trade known to those unscrupulous cretins whose livelihood is the confinement, torture and extraordinarily brutal extermination of innocent beings - all in the name of fickle "luxury" and transient, superfluous "fashion."

As the height of the shopping season approaches,  CAAF will stage another demo at the high-profile fur-dealing Bergdorf-Goodman Dept. store on 5th Avenue in New York City. Let's not miss this EXTRAORDINARY opportunity to get the message of compassion for animals trapped in the bloody fur trade out to the public!

Come and add your voice to a burgeoning group of energetic animal activists whose prime directive is to elevate public awareness about the plight of innumerable defenseless foxes, minks, raccoons, dogs and cats and other mammal victims of the gruesome Chinese fur trade, who are violently and systematically removed from their natural habitats, corralled into inescapable death camps, crammed into tiny, filthy cages for months in ALL weather conditions, beaten, stomped on, anally electrocuted, gassed, bludgeoned to death, even SKINNED ALIVE so that affluent first-world consumers can gleefully, obliviously parade around, morbidly draped in the skins that are, quite literally, ripped off these animals' backs as they helplessly writhe in overwhelming shock and agony 'til the final throes of death overtake them. For many of these unfortunate creatures, that means the agony lasts for minutes or even hours!

These helpless animals are tortured and killed in the most horrifically cruel ways imaginable - all for vain, pretentious, human notions of "luxury apparel" and "fashion." Jump into the ongoing campaign to STOP this insanity and work toward the total abolition of the global fur industry. Come out and HELP US make a vocal, public impact for the animals trapped and languishing in this insidious death trade, and to send a meaningful message to the heartless people who line their pockets with blood and entrails, who build their posh castles with the unspeakable screams of terror and suffering from countless innocent beings. For those unfamiliar with the realities of the horrible global fur trade, please take a few minutes to watch the following ( Warning: Graphic imagery!):

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ueBWi8BL0PQ

Disgusting? Horrible? Unforgivable? Agreed, so PLEASE come and help us to vocalize our extreme objection to this inexcusable, retrograde, medieval barbarism, to discourage/deter potential fur-shoppers from patronizing this retail dealer in death and torture, to enlighten the public to the grim realities behind their whimsical, self-deluding notions of fashion, and to encourage them to make more compassionate choices in shopping for winter apparel. In a world with so many great (and more economical) cruelty-free fabrics and styles, there really is ABSOLUTELY NO EXCUSE for this ongoing madness.

WHAT: ** CAAF Don't Buy Fur! demo @ Bergdorf-Goodman on 5th Ave, NYC **

WHERE: Bergdorf-Goodman Dept. Store, 754 5th Ave (btwn 57th & 58th)

New York, NY 10001.

WHEN: Saturday, December 19th, 2015

TIME: 1:00 ~ 3:00pm

Activists are invited to gather from 1:00pm forward on the public sidewalk in front of Bergdorf-Goodman. If there are any questions about directions to and from this location in Manhattan, please call Caring Activists Against Fur @ [masked] or send an email to [masked].

We will have plenty of signs, literature and relevant props to share with interested members of the general public. All YOU need to bring is yourself and your voice to speak up for the voiceless, who cannot articulate their own wish to freely live out their lives under the sun, to frolic and to bear young, to behave in accordance with their own natures with no interference from our species.

For more information on this demo, and upcoming anti-fur events, send an email to [masked] or call [masked]. Come out and help us in our efforts to make the world a kinder and more compassionate one for all our animal friends. There is no justice, there is JUST US , WE are their voices!!!!
results.name: CAAF 'Don't Buy Fur!' demo @ Bergdorf-Goodman on 5th Ave in NYC

results.description:
Our next meetup will focus on: Happiness.

The meetup runs as follows:


1) The moderator selects one subject for discussion and a date for the meeting. Subjects can be as ephemeral as "love," "god," and "purpose," or as grounded as "politics," "environmentalism," and "family."

2) At the meetup, people are encouraged to propose a question related to the subject. The moderator will collect all of the questions in a list. Questions may also be proposed ahead of time online on the event page.

3) The group will then vote on the questions. In the first round of voting, each individual may vote for as many questions as they like. The top three will then go to a second round, where each individual may vote just once.

4) The question with the most votes is then discussed. Often, the discussion starts with a narrowing of the question, as it can be challenging to devise a question that can possibly be answered by a small group in just a couple of hours' discussion.

Finally, please consider making a small donation to help the moderator cover subscription costs.
results.name: Let's Talk About: Happiness

results.description: In 1806 William Thornhill, an illiterate English bargeman and a man of quick temper but deep compassion, steals a load of wood and, as a part of his lenient sentence, is deported, along with his beloved wife, Sal, to the New South Wales colony in what would become Australia. The Secret River is the tale of William and Sal’s deep love for their small, exotic corner of the new world, and William’s gradual realization that if he wants to make a home for his family, he must forcibly take the land from the people who came before him. Acclaimed around the world, The Secret River is a magnificent, transporting work of historical fiction.
results.name: December -- The Secret River by Kate Grenville

results.description:
Why is it that award-winning books seem to always be so darn depressing? Failed love, tormented criminals, abusive childhoods? Fortunately, the annual Thurber Prize was established in 1997 to honor outstanding examples of American humor. This award is named for James Thurber who died in 1961 and who was one of the most admired and controversial humorists of the first half of the 20th century. 

The 13 Clocks is a fantasy fairytale written in a unique cadenced style, in which a mysterious prince must complete a seemingly impossible task to free a maiden from the clutches of an evil duke. The story is noted for Thurber's constant, complex wordplay, and his use of an almost continuous internal meter, with occasional hidden rhymes — akin to blank verse, but with no line breaks to advertise the structure. Other fantasy books by Thurber, such as The Wonderful O, also contained hints of this unusual prose form. 

Not convinced? Just check out the opening paragraph: 

"Once upon a time, in a gloomy castle on a lonely hill, where there were thirteen clocks that wouldn’t go, there lived a cold, aggressive Duke, and his niece, the Princess Saralinda. She was warm in every wind and weather, but he was always cold. His hands were as cold as his smile, and almost as cold as his heart. He wore gloves when he was asleep, and he wore gloves when he was awake, which made it difficult for him to pick up pins or coins or the kernels of nuts, or to tear the wings from nightingales."

And at only 130 pages, this fairytale seems like a perfect light-hearted romp of a read for the holidays.
results.name: James Thurber's The 13 Clocks

Game description:
We'll play two simultaneous games of 7 on 7.
There will be 4 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team.

RULES OF THE GAME:
First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field!
Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.
No power shots allowed.
If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.
If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.
Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game.
Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Please check our meetup message board on Friday night or before 12:00 PM on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

Location and Directions:

Sara D. Roosevelt Park, Nike Field
Take the F train to 2nd Avenue Lower East Side, and walk for about 3 minutes on Chrystie Street to the Nike Field between Stanton St & Rivington St
New York, NY 10002
Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S.

A positive attitude, pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water.

Fee:
You will be asked to pay $9.50 dollars when you RSVP. This $9.50 dollars is used to pay for, permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:
Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled.
The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

****READ THIS FIRST || Parade Grounds Game Standards ****


Meet on field 8!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 2:00. We typically start 15 minutes after 2:00. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.

Ever heard the expression "it takes two to tango"? Well, for this class, experience what that is like! Take part in the elegant and traditional style of Argentine Tango in a friendly and supportive community of dancers.

results.description:
Our typical agenda: - We orient new visitors and then chat a bit, as by sharing what's new or good in our lives. - Then we chant and meditate together, together with the beautiful sounds of a gong - And finally we share thoughts and questions, learning something new sometimes, generally supporting each other best we can at all times.

Note that we meet every Wednesday, 7:30 to 9 pm, and every Saturday, 2 to 3:30 pm on Midchester Ave. -- except for the first Saturday of the month, when we meet elsewhere and begin our meeting at 5 pm, followed by an informal potluck social starting about 7 pm.

(When you plan on staying for the potluck, see the log-in information posted at our monthly potluck page. That helps us get healthy, balanced meals.)

By the way, the meetup page may show only a few members planning to attend a particular meeting. That's because many people attend regularly and don't bother to RSVP for each meeting.  We never have only a few members at a meeting. Twenty members more usually attend each meeting.

Call Merrill or Mataji anytime you have questions:[masked]-5334.
results.name: American Meditation Society - Weekly Saturday Meetup in White Plains

results.description:
Basic Ground Rules for Participation

Please wear either a blue/black or white shirt to make things easy (Preferably bring both in case we need to mix the teams more evenly).


no need to respond at all if you can't/don't want to play

• if you do respond IN, please come unless something really urgent comes up (hangovers or better offers from your cooler friends not accepted for absences!)


• If you suck at Ultimate... you are more than welcome. This is open to ALL skill levels, ages etc. If you're really good, please pretend you suck every once in a while for the benefit of the rest of us! We're just here to run around and have fun. We all want to score and win but if you want to win at all costs, this is not the game for you.

• The trick with this group is making sure we have enough to play, so those who do show up don't waste a trip, so please make the effort this year to be honest with yourself and us about if you can/want to come down so we can make the right call for GAME ON or GAME OFF. If you are a "maybe" please indicate that via the comment section with a brief explanation (ie 80% chance I'll be there...). If you RSVP and are then unable to attend, please update your RSVP as soon as possible.

What is Ultimate Frisbee? In a nutshell <borrowed from Wiki> :

Ultimate is a limited-contact team field sport played with a disc (frisbee). Points are scored by passing the disc to a teammate in the opposing end zone. Other basic rules are that players must not take steps while holding the disc (maintain a pivot), and interceptions and incomplete passes are turnovers.

Closest analogy I could come up with = a mix of basketball and football, but played with a frisbee. You do not need to be an expert frisbee player/thrower etc. - it's all about having fun.
results.name: NEW TIME - Saturday Ultimate Frisbee (Anderson Park)

results.description:
This Event: 

The aim of this weekly event is to offer a place where Python developers and learners can come and ask questions or give help. 

Individuals of all programming skill levels are welcome. 

It is suggested that you bring your own laptop. If you don't have access to a laptop and want to attend, please let Paul Logston know and he will see about getting you a laptop for the day.

This event is free. 

This event is not a tutorial. Tutorials hosted by Learn Python NYC are labeled as tutorials.

Resources:

Here are some learning resources and free text editor / IDE suggestions.

https://github.com/logston/NYCPythonSOH/blob/master/resources.rst 

Detailed Directions to us:

As you enter the building located at 568 Broadway, New York, NY 10012 you will need to provide ID and your destination (Fueled Collective, 11th Floor) to the front desk. They will provide you with a sticker badge. Take one of the elevators (located to the right of the front desk) to the 11th floor. We will be in the Deerbrook conference room.
results.how_to_find_us: Show ID at front desk, come up to 11th floor, we are in the Deerbrook conference room!
results.name: Saturday Python Study Group

results.description:
It's the December edition of our popular monthly GUY GALLERY WALK!


Full itinerary as follows:


1. ROBERT MILLER GALLERY (524 W 26th St) presents: YAYOI KUSAMA, 'LADDER TO HEAVEN'

2. GALERIE LELONG (528 W 26th St) presents: YOKO ONO, 'RIVERBED PT I'

Yoko Ono—a forerunner in Conceptual art involving collaboration, audience participation and social activism—will present a double exhibition, THE RIVERBED, at Galerie Lelong and Andrea Rosen Gallery. Following her recent exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, New York, these interactive exhibitions are comprised of two entirely new, full gallery installations.THE RIVERBED will open to the public on December 11, 2015 and continue through January 23, 2016 at Andrea Rosen Gallery and January 29, 2016 at Galerie Lelong. The artist will be present at the openings.

Since the early 1960s, audience participation has been a crucial aspect of Ono’s work. To make a village is a political gesture, as well as a formal one. Audience participation is key to completing THE RIVERBED through everyday action coupled with contemplation; they are collaborators with the artist, similar to the collaboration between the artist and the two galleries. Additionally, it is significant to Ono that all three “principals”— the artist and two gallery leaders—are female; the support and participation of women in power is one of Ono’s longstanding concerns.  

Conceived as two room-sized installations shown in two spaces—a whole in two parts—visitors are encouraged, via instructions, to visit both spaces in order to experience and fully understand THE RIVERBED. Both galleries will have a pile of large river stones that Ono has selected and gathered. She will inscribe words like remember, dream, and wish on the stones, which have been honed and shaped by water over time. Visitors may pick up stones and hold it in their laps, concentrating on the word and letting go of their anger or fear, transforming the stone into an emotional object to be placed upon the pile of stones in the center of the room. Additional instructions on paper will encourage you to “draw a line to take me to the farthest place in our planet.” Like the Wish Tree, THE RIVERBED becomes a repository of hopes and dreams for individuals and the world. Uniting two separate physical spaces and environments, Ono will create a temporary, but real, village that brings Hikari (light in Japanese) to each space and viewer.  Another aspect is to see the difference between the installations at both spaces.  Though ostensibly the same, they will each evolve differently over time, in part because of how the viewer interacts with the materials.  These differences will be recorded, providing an opportunity to see that Ono's works are not only about audience participation, but how the effect has a significance within the work.

Mend Piece, an installation that has been shown in a number of Ono’s retrospectives, will reinforce the idea of healing and will be shown in the smaller rooms at both galleries. Fragments of broken cups are placed on a table for the audience to mend with tape, string, glue or other materials and then placed on shelves around the all white room, reminiscent of a dream. The metaphor of mending and healing are close. In Ono’s words: ”As you mend the cup, mending that is needed elsewhere in the Universe gets done as well. Be aware of it as you mend.” Following their mending, the participants may have an actual cup of coffee, forming another kind of temporary village.

3. JAMES COHAN GALLERY (533 W 26th) presents: BILL VIOLA, 'INVERTED BIRTH'


Regarded as a seminal figure in the development of video art, Viola has been celebrated throughout his 40-year career for combining state-of-the-art technology with universal humanistic themes – birth, death, and the unfolding of consciousness. These themes continue in Viola’s Inverted Birth, which explores the life cycle as a continuum rather than a linear progression. Viola has remarked, “Birth is not a beginning, death is not an end.


In the main gallery, Viola’s monumental video and audio installation Inverted Birth is projected onto a fifteen-foot high screen anchored to the floor. The work depicts five stages of awakening through a series of violent transformations. the heat of summer.  Each work is shown on a vertical LCD screen, and installed one on each of the four walls, creating an immersive environment in the gallery’s last room.  Four figures are silently and gradually overcome by the four elements of nature. As Viola describes: “Flames rain down, winds begin to lash, water cascades, and earth flies up. As the elements rage, each martyr’s resolve remains unchanged. In their most violent assault, the elements represent the darkest hour of the martyr’s passage through death into the light.” 

4. PAUL KASMIN GALLERY [masked]th Ave) presents: ERIK PARKER, 'UNDERTOW'

His iconic, highly-saturated palette and intricate compositions are amplified by collage and airbrush techniques that create a balance of density and open space.


Undertow marks the artist’s third solo-exhibition with the gallery and offers insight into the evolution of Parker’s work over the last two decades. Here, Parker continues to critically chart the world’s current political, social, and economic landscapes with compositions brimming with references to media, popular culture, music, and art history. Synthesizing multiple elements from his myriad styles into new dynamic compositions, the artist works at breaking down the metanarratives of late modernist painting while simultaneously digesting the pictorial chatter of scrolling feeds of social media.


Highlighted in the exhibition are Parker’s new shaped canvases with which he develops the narrative possibilities of form. In Offshore, 2015 the support structure of the canvas takes the shape of binocular lenses, framing the action as if seen from afar. Parker’s large-scale, two-part shaped canvas titled Disconnected, 2015, features a pyramid representing the global elite. It is physically separated from the second canvas – literally leaving the rest of the picture, or perhaps, society behind.

5. PAUL KASMIN GALLERY [masked]th Ave) presents: MARK RYDEN, 'DODECAHEDRON'


The vocabulary of images in Ryden’s new body of work remains consistent with his pervasive distortion of scale and his iconic fairytale-like creatures set against seductive landscapes of untouched beauty. However, the subject of his latest series is informed by the geometric structure “dodecahedron,” a solid figure bearing twelve sides whose perfect symmetry has been the source of extensive query by mathematicians and scientists since antiquity. Drawing upon the form’s mystery and divine connotations as a source of inspiration, Ryden explores the bridge between the physical world and the intangible realm.


For the exhibition, Ryden created his first sculpture cast from bronze. Measuring one meter in height, the work consists of twelve pentagonal panels that join together to form a dodecahedron. Each panel is individually cast and features images and motifs that have been prevalent throughout the artist’s oeuvre such as; the tree, the eye, the fetus, the bee, the ammonite, and Abraham Lincoln.


Ryden’s labor-intensive canvases skillfully rework centuries of art history, combining the grandeur of Spanish and Italian religious painting with the decorative richness of Old Master compositions and the lush textures of French Neo-Classicism. Expanding on these concepts, the artist’s paintings focus on “the soul confronting its physical form” as represented by his reoccurring feminine child figure, he calls “anima” or “soul” figure. These anima figures appear under different guises, such as in Anatomia, 2015 and Aurora, 2015. For the artist, they represent the part of us that wonders at the elegant mathematics that exists underneath everything and the sacred geometry that constructs our physical world.


6. PACE GALLERY (510 W 25th St) present: ILYA & EMILIA KABAKOV, 'NEW PAINTINGS'


7. YOSSI MILO GALLERY [masked]th Ave)  presents: GROUP SHOW, 'I AM A LIE AND I AM GOLD'

an exhibition about photography without the inclusion of a single photograph. Curated by artist Marco Breuer, the exhibition features drawings, paintings, sculptures, textiles, and installations by 25 artists who engage with a wide range of photographic issues. This exhibition is based on the idea that photography is a principle, not a product.


The ubiquity of photography has a considerable equalizing effect. Everything eventually ends up as a photograph—every experience, every piece of matter is sooner or later translated into a photograph, and then of course shared, and used as a measuring stick for all future experiences. Photography is at once the most public and the most private of mediums. It is an ever-shifting practice that manifests in many hybrid forms.

Photography in all its manifestations has had an enormous influence on other art forms. Artists from Monet to Gerhard Richter have not only based their works on photographic images, they have often borrowed the very concept of photography itself. Many artists have a complicated relationship to the medium, at times working less with and more against photography. David Hockney once said: “Photography is all right if you don’t mind looking at the world from the point of view of a paralyzed Cyclops, for a split second.”

8. ANDREA ROSEN GALLERY (525 W 24th St) presents: YOKO ONO, 'RIVERBED PT II'

Yoko Ono—a forerunner in Conceptual art involving collaboration, audience participation and social activism—will present a double exhibition, THE RIVERBED, at Galerie Lelong and Andrea Rosen Gallery. Following her recent exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, New York, these interactive exhibitions are comprised of two entirely new, full gallery installations.THE RIVERBED will open to the public on December 11, 2015 and continue through January 23, 2016 at Andrea Rosen Gallery and January 29, 2016 at Galerie Lelong. The artist will be present at the openings.


Since the early 1960s, audience participation has been a crucial aspect of Ono’s work. To make a village is a political gesture, as well as a formal one. Audience participation is key to completing THE RIVERBED through everyday action coupled with contemplation; they are collaborators with the artist, similar to the collaboration between the artist and the two galleries. Additionally, it is significant to Ono that all three “principals”— the artist and two gallery leaders—are female; the support and participation of women in power is one of Ono’s longstanding concerns.  

Conceived as two room-sized installations shown in two spaces—a whole in two parts—visitors are encouraged, via instructions, to visit both spaces in order to experience and fully understand THE RIVERBED. Both galleries will have a pile of large river stones that Ono has selected and gathered. She will inscribe words like remember, dream, and wish on the stones, which have been honed and shaped by water over time. Visitors may pick up stones and hold it in their laps, concentrating on the word and letting go of their anger or fear, transforming the stone into an emotional object to be placed upon the pile of stones in the center of the room. Additional instructions on paper will encourage you to “draw a line to take me to the farthest place in our planet.” Like the Wish Tree, THE RIVERBED becomes a repository of hopes and dreams for individuals and the world. Uniting two separate physical spaces and environments, Ono will create a temporary, but real, village that brings Hikari (light in Japanese) to each space and viewer.  Another aspect is to see the difference between the installations at both spaces.  Though ostensibly the same, they will each evolve differently over time, in part because of how the viewer interacts with the materials.  These differences will be recorded, providing an opportunity to see that Ono's works are not only about audience participation, but how the effect has a significance within the work.

Mend Piece, an installation that has been shown in a number of Ono’s retrospectives, will reinforce the idea of healing and will be shown in the smaller rooms at both galleries. Fragments of broken cups are placed on a table for the audience to mend with tape, string, glue or other materials and then placed on shelves around the all white room, reminiscent of a dream. The metaphor of mending and healing are close. In Ono’s words: ”As you mend the cup, mending that is needed elsewhere in the Universe gets done as well. Be aware of it as you mend.” Following their mending, the participants may have an actual cup of coffee, forming another kind of temporary village.

9. MIKE WEISS GALLERY (520 W 24th St) presents: STEFANIE GUTHIEL, 'THE HOSUE OF MR. PEEPS'

the Berlin-based artist has delved deep into the recesses of her imagination – back where horned beasts, laser beams, onesies, a brass marching band, phonographs, multi-talented chickens, the original stooge named Krampus and a giant pink elephant all reside – and emerged with a phantasmagoric stable of characters à la a secularized and hallucinatory version of Noah’s Arc. With this herd of misfit creatures, Gutheil has left normality at the door and transformed the gallery into a sanctuary of the bizarre – a surreal, utopic landscape of chromatic and psychological vibrancy.

With all their quirks and foibles in plain sight, the artist’s fantastical creatures appear to us as friends and intimates. In fact, it is precisely because of the alluring, almost childlike honesty inherent in the figures unabashed eccentricities that connection with the works is nearly inevitable. Yet there is more to these characters than their carnivalesque appearance; in each, Gutheil has instilled an emotional gravity that seems both personally derived and universally comprehensible. Sometimes the sentiment is uplifting – for example in A Walk in the Forest, where we find two cronies strutting with emoticon-worthy smiles strewn across their faces.  Other times, the mood isn’t always so chummy.  In Safe Bet, it is impossible to say with certainty whether the winged yet dense-looking humanoid is falling down or flying upward, if it has walked the plank by force or leapt from the diving board by choice. 

In their peculiar features and with their hearts on their sleeves, Gutheil’s oddballs all emit a vaguely familiar sense of the folkloric, as if the artist unraveled them from traditional fables and stitched together her own. 

10. HOERLE-GUGGENHEIM (527 W 23rd St) presents: DAVID WELKER, 'SUBCONSCIOUS NARRATIVES'

Welker has followed a path of experimentation and genre jumping taking him from the top of the landscape mural scene to the top of the concert poster scene in just a few years. Welker is now setting his sights on the gallery world as he continues to express all of his varied influences in a unified visual aesthetic which combines his deep appreciation of early 20th century Surrealism with his love of pervasive pop culture.

With Subconscious Narratives Welker depicts a thought before it becomes a word, concept, story or tangible form. These studies are not isolated to one brief instant but instead capture the turmoil of forms transitioning in the mind from moment to moment. By getting in tune with his minds eye Welker has noticed that the periphery of each thought has edges fading into others. His imagination hovers in a space devoid of temporal constraints or physical permanence. This is the conceptual DNA of Subconscious Narratives - an exploration of the cloudy impressions leading up to and receding from a fabricated instance. While the center of the pieces may be a conceptual focus, the edges form building blocks for dreams not yet depicted. The subconscious narrative barely holds onto the present while the past and future drive into being. Its beginning is another’s middle and end.

11. ANDREW KREPS GALLERY (537 W 22nd St) presents: WALKS AND DICPLACEMENTS, GROUP SHOW

an exhibition that brings together eleven artists whose work reflects an engagement with pre-existing source materials. Working in disparate media, they share a lyrical approach that works to abstract the original while maintaining its integrity, creating new aesthetic and emotive experiences with objects, images, bodies, videos and sounds. What emerges across these investigations are shared sensibilities, as well as overlapping strategies of erosion, stratification, embedding, and association. This allows the exhibition to unfold similarly to the works themselves – a walk from one place to another, that bears with it the accumulative traces of both decisions made, and what one carries with them.

12. DANESE COREY GALLERY (511 W 22nd St) presents: DORON LANGBERG and GABY-COLLINS FERNANDEZ, group show

Doron Langberg and Gaby Collins-Fernandez. As students at Yale University, they became friends; as artists, they share studio space and enjoy a continuing dialogue about painting and the very nature of art.


Langberg has said, “using a sexual image can be a powerful vehicle” to demonstrate a broad range of emotions – desire and loss, vulnerability and tenderness. While his paintings are formed by deeply felt personal experience, they transcend their homoerotic content and embrace the universal human condition. He views the figurative tradition through a prism that references art history – Ingres, Bonnard, Manet, Whistler, Homer.

Collins-Fernandez employs seductive materials in her intimately scaled works, animating the surfaces with thick applications of pigment and strips and swags of velvet – its textural delights and associations with garments, curtains, and costume. Snippets of New York street conversation, captured fragments of a highly energetic and diverse urban culture, are embedded within the dense topography of her paintings.

13. DAVID ZWIRNER GALLERY (537 W 20th St) presents: GIORGIO MORANDI, WORKS FROM 1940'S-1960'S

David Zwirner is pleased to present an exhibition of paintings from the 1940s to the 1960s by the celebrated Italian artist Giorgio Morandi (1890- 1964) on view at our 537 West 20th Street location in New York. The first major exhibition of Morandi’s later work in America since the acclaimed 2008 retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, the show will focus primarily on the period during which he developed and refined his investigations of serial, reductive, and permutational forms and compositions—aspects that had a profound influence on twentieth-century and contemporary art and painting. The exhibition will include important loans from institutions such as the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C., as well as from numerous significant private collections.

14. JACK SHAINMAN GALLERY (513 W 20th St) presents  TOYIN OJIH ODUTOLAOF, 'CONTEXT AND WITHOUT'

Ojih Odutola incorporates chalk, ink, pen, and marker into textured portraits addressing the interplay between line and form, as well as context and perception. The subjects in the exhibition have been pulled from the vastness of everyday imagery, but Ojih Odutola transforms them into studies of mark-making and material, the results denying placement in any stable setting. 

15. DAVID ZWIRNER GALLERY (519 W 19th St) presents: JAMES WELLING, 'CHOREOGRAPH'

Choreograph debuts a series of digital photographs of dance, with elements of architecture and/or landscape. These were made by placing three different black-and-white photographs into Adobe Photoshop’s red, green, and blue color channels, thus yielding a multilayered color image similar to double exposures in analog photography. The artist then alters it using Photoshop tools (hue/saturation and selective color), and as adjustments are made, various parts of the image come forward or recede.


Welling’s interest in dance dates back to 1970 when he saw the Merce Cunningham Dance Company perform while at university in Pittsburgh. He took dance classes at the time, but after transferring to the California Institute of the Arts, he turned to photography as his medium. This exhibition marks his return to dance, albeit in photographic form.

FEE: $5.00 for regular members; FREE for full-paid members!

results.description:
Note: If you are planning on attending this meetup please RSVP. I want to be able to know how many people are coming for a given session. Thank you.

Lesson: We will be discussing New York City Survival Guide: tips and Etiquettes. Special tips for women's safety too.



 I often see members of this group looking for time to study English, so I would like to give the non-native English speakers in our group an opportunity to improve their English just like they have given us the chance to improve our Chinese, Japanese, or Korean skills.

I also hope that by extending this opportunity, we will encourage more native speakers of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean to participate and aid our CJK practice on Wednesdays.

Our practice will include games, discussion, and reading activities. Please look for a notice from me about what activities we will doing each Saturday.

Any and all suggestions for methods, activities, etc. are welcome.

This group was created to function as an exchange. We help you and you help us.

How to find us...

Go to 53rd street and Lexington Ave. The building is across the street from a CVS pharmacy on 53rd St, there are two main entrances. The top entrance in the picture is on 53rd St between Lexington avenue and 3rd avenue. The bottom entrance is on the corner of 53rd St and Lexington avenue. The building is called the Citigroup Center but the area where we sit is also called the Atrium Shops and Cafes. Which is located on the bottom floor: a big open area which has many round and square tables and chairs. The ZIP CODE is 10022. If you still have problems finding us look for a high rise glass building. Barnes and Nobles and 24 Hr Fitness are also located in the same building except on the upper level. If you enter on the upper levels then take the escalator down to ground floor where all the people and tables are.
results.name: English Study and Practice for Non-Native Speakers

results.description:
[Cross-posted from NYC Stoics]

Our theme for 2015 has been "modern Stoicism." We covered William Irvine's practical take on how to live a modern Stoic life, Lawrence Becker's more theoretical approach, and we also examined how modern ethics (virtue and otherwise) ties in with modern Stoic theory and practice.

In this final meetup of 2015, we will wrap up our theme of modern Stoicism by discussing how to live a Stoic life in modern times. Specifically, the meetup will be structured as follows:

• First, we'll tackle the question of whether modernity presents any special challenges to contemporary Stoics. Has human nature or our culture changed in the past two millennia so that certain aspects of ancient Stoicism may need to be adjusted for modern times and sensibilities?

• Next, we'll discuss methods for figuring out the question of "what would a modern Stoic do?" Can we talk in generalities, or must we work on a case-by-case basis? During this part of the meetup, we'll review Becker's take on the matter and also review the similarities and differences between ancient and modern ethics

• Then, we'll attempt to answer some general modern dilemmas from a Stoic perspective to see if and how this approach is fruitful

• Finally, we'll have time for personal questions about your own modern life and how a modern Stoic practice could tie into it

There will be no readings for this meetup. To prepare, please think about the following questions/topics and have your own answers for them:

• What are the specific challenges of living a Stoic life in New York City in the 21st century?

• How would you think through the question of what a modern Stoic would do? What's your preferred method?

• Come up with a general ethical or daily-living dilemma for the group to think through to see what a modern Stoic would do in that case. It can be anything from something abstract like the trolley problem to something more practical like how a Stoic would ride the subway.

• If you're comfortable with it, think of a personal issue you would like to bring up to the group to examine from a Stoic perspective.
results.name: What Would A Modern Stoic Do?

Join us for an afternoon of figure drawing! Burlesque models, victorian costumes, and other experimental themes weekly.

Starts at 2:30PM at Muchmore's- Take the L train to Bedford ave, the address is 2 Havemeyer st (between Withers St & 9th St)

Drop-in and cash only, donation of $10-$15 gets you 2 and half hours of drawing time! Come early, stay late - drinks specials and excellent oslo coffee is served. We're in the side room and it's incredibly cozy; couches, tables and easels if you prefer to stand.

results.description:
Hi Single Parents -

Chelsea Piers is always a blast for parents and kids of all ages.  Last year we exceeded (by far) the limit on how many people could attend so this year RSVPs will probably be capped.

Chelsea Piers is offering a deeply discounted and custom play day just for us and our kids. We will meet at the Field House, in Studio A, where we will have plenty of space to meet & socialize with each other. Younger kids will have access to the Toddler Gym, and older kids will head over to the basketball courts for a two-hour long Ultimate Challenge that will include basketball, dodge ball, relay races and tugs of war.

We're getting the same rate as last time ($15 per kid/parents free) which is a great deal. 

Also exciting is that we'll have:

Our own area to meet, give kids lunch, etc.

Activities will be for kids of all ages

There will be coaches there just for us

It will just be us!

Last time we hit the Chelsea Brewery after the event. Unfortunately, they're no longer around but there are other options like Wichcraft.

Now, we've committed to a certain attendance so please PLEASE RSVP EITHER WAY ASAP. Read below for more information.

Thanks and see you there.

------

More from the folks at Chelsea Piers...

3pm - 5pm. Studio A connects to the Toddler Adventure Center, one of the finest toddler play areas in the city. Featuring state-of-the-art equipment, your kids will be in the perfect environment for exploration, learning, adventure and fun! The Toddler Adventure Center is designed for children ages 4 and under.

3pm - 5pm, a special Ultimate Challenge is planned! The Ultimate Challenge includes some of the most popular games to create a truly unique experience for your child. Games include tug-of-war, dodgeball, scooter races and more! We will lower the basketball nets for your young ones and batting cage tokens are available for purchase, as well. Please note: All ages can participate in the Ultimate Challenge and your child must be at least 5 years old to swing in the batting cages.
results.name: Single Parents December Meetup - Chelsea Piers Custom Play Day

results.description:
This is a class in technique although, when you've conquered a song technically, then I will coach musicality and performance. Class size is limited. Fee is $20/per. You may audit the class once (without participating) for $10. Let me know when you sign up if that's your intention.

   People at the front desk are helpful and friendly and the Cafe on the floor has great coffee and cookies, sandwiches, <a>pizza</a>, etc.

   I've been asked to post this:

Dear Members:  This is the first you have heard from me. I am Mr. Harrington's agent/rep. Mr. Harrington teaches privately coaching established actors and singers. For years his private rate has been $120/hr for this service. He started teaching through Meetup earlier this year and has as his goal to bring professional level instruction to the public at a rate that leaves no one behind. This demands tight scheduling of both his time and the room rental with Ripley-Grier Studios.For these reasons, I will be insisting to him that "no shows" be dropped from the group. The policy is this: If you RSVP you better show up. If you cancel you better do this by 4:00 pm the previous day.A word to the wise...Michael T. Harvey
results.how_to_find_us: Check the electronic billboard opposite the elevators on floor 16.

There was so much to talk about with Aspects (and getting a little sidetracked), that I decided to have an Aspects part II meetup, where we continue to talk about Aspects, and go more in depth with the lesser aspects (quincunxes, sesquintiles, etc), and how though minor, they can still effect your psychology. 

If anyone has any suggestions about what you'd like the Meetup to be about, feel free to message me. I'm not opposed to changing the topic.
results.name: Aspects Part II!

Big Boss Man

Bertha

Sugaree

Cold Rain and Snow

GDTRFB

Beat It On Down the Line

Friend of the Devil

Sugar Magnolia

Brokedown Palace

What we haven't been doing is working on some of the bigger jam vehicle tunes. We should make a spot in the third hour just after the 'Safety Meeting in the Stairwell' jam to bust out an Eyes, Dark Star, ScarletFire, etc.

We should go through these until we devolve into the usual 'call something out clockwise setlist'

I'll sign up for drums. If another drummer signs up I will rent the congas and split the time. If two bass players sign up, we will look into another room.

results.description:
One of my last meetups for 2015!

I want to share with you guys my thoughts on developing a lifestyle where meeting attractive members of the opposite sex is the NORM and not the EXCEPTION.

Most of us have a hard time just meeting new friends, much less attractive people that we want to go out with.

I'm going to share how I developed the ability to meet attractive women in my daily life almost effortlessly, and 5 specific steps for you to do the same.

We will also have time for a discussion, so bring your questions and current challenges.

Ripley-Grier Studios

520 8th Ave

Room 16W

3-4pm

See you there!

Justin

http://JustinAttraction.com

http://NaturalAttractionNYC.com
results.how_to_find_us: Room 16W
results.name: The Lifestyle of Meeting the Opposite Sex: Free Talk

results.description:
Our monthly meetup to discuss two articles. If you would like to suggest an article, please do so in the comments below. RSVPs will open two weeks before day of meetup.  Priority on the waitlist will be given to individuals who have previously contributed to good discussion, posted a thoughtful comment or suggested an article.

This month's theme is, no home. A timely discussion around this time of the year, to remind ourselves of how much we have to appreciate while others may have none. The first selection is a two year old article from the New Yorker magazine about the homeless population in new york city. The second article is about the story of a young man, who leaves the dangers of his home in Syria for Europe and ends up in Sweden. 

They should both make for great discussion. Looking forward to seeing everyone there.

Article 1: 

Hidden City


http://www.wnyc.org/series/long-way-home/


More recent data on homeless from CFH


Article 2: 

Ten Borders
results.name: December Meetup: No Home

results.description:
Hanging Wax Vimanas are hand-made miniature wax sculptures infused with crayon, oil pastel, mixed wax oils arranged in a vertical array using raw materials such as stone, shell, clay, and wood.

A "Vimana" is a word with several meanings ranging from temple or palace to mythological flying machines described in Sanskrit epics. References to these flying machines are mentioned in ancient Vedic text.

More info and tickets: https://goo.gl/qVJSZy

results.description:
Prepay here:

https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=R9MJCSE8CQNSU

=============================================

Soho, although boasting the greatest collection of cast-iron architecture in the world, in the 1960's was almost demolished by Robert Moses for a planned highway across Manhattan.  Saved by activists like Jane Jacobs, it became a center of the contemporary art movement in NYC for almost 20 years, with figures such as Phillip Glass, Twyla Tharp, Nam June Paik, Meredith Monk and Chuck Close helping to make the neighborhood even hipper.  Come and see galleries that still retain some of this avant-garde feel. (Note: We may also venture into nearby areas, such as Tribeca.)

The tour will be led by Savona Bailey-McClain, founder and executive director of the West Harlem Art Fund, an organization that promotes art and culture in parks and other open spaces across NYC, as well as galleries. She has been involved in numerous public art installations and was recently selected to join TINA, a new international network for contemporary art curators based in Italy. 

IMPORTANT: 

- Prepay here:

https://www.paypal.com/cgi-bin/webscr?cmd=_s-xclick&hosted_button_id=R9MJCSE8CQNSU

- If you tried to use the above link but had trouble with Paypal, an alternate payment link on Brown Paper Tickets will be emailed upon request. This will require an extra $1 charge to help cover the higher fees with this processor. 

- On December 18 (one day before), the price will go up to $25 if the event has not sold out.  Purchasing your spot as early as possible is recommended.

- RSVP without payment does NOT reserve your spot or lock in the price.

- Online payment deadline is 10:30am on the day of the tour.

- If space is available, payment can be made on-site ($25, cash only).

- Sorry, refunds and exchanges are not available (unless the event is cancelled).  However, if you are unable to attend, you can send someone in your place.  At check-in, simply have him or her mention the name under which you paid.

- If you are late or having trouble finding the group, call or text (917) 680-0656.  This is not a smartphone, so posting comments or sending messages through the Meetup site will NOT work.

- Please remember to bring photo ID in case it is requested by security at some of the galleries.

- Feel free to bring your camera.  Taking pictures is allowed.

- The tour will last approximately two hours.  Afterward, we will go somewhere nearby for food and socializing if there is interest.

- Art novices are welcome, as are people with extensive art backgrounds.

- This event is exclusively for members of my meetup groups and their guests, plus special invitees.  It is not open to the general public.


See you there! 

Milton & Savona


UPDATE: ONLINE PAYMENTS NOW CLOSED. PAYMENT ACCEPTED ON SITE ($25 PER PERSON, CASH ONLY)
results.how_to_find_us: Meeting point is just past (west of) the subway entrance for the R train on Prince Street.

results.description:
Take a break from shopping to network with others interested in their personal or professional growth. Network for the first 45 minutes, and then walk through a process to support you in setting your achievable goals for 2016.

Bring a notepad and pen! Feel free to bring some light snacks or holiday treats for others - I will have some snacks and juice there, too!

Katie

p.s. here is information prepared for the Bloomfield Library about the event:

NE NJ Personal and Professional Development Networking MeetUp Group presents:

VISION YOUR 2016 NETWORKING EVENT and WORKSHOP

When:

Saturday, Dec. 19th from 3 - 4:30 p.m.

SPACE LIMITED

RSVP required / Wait list after limit

Where:

Bloomfield Public Library

90 Broad Street  Bloomfield, NJ 07003

http://www.bplnj.org

This Event / Workshop Is For You If:

·  You want to meet people in the area who are interested in their own development and in supporting others.

·  You‘ve achieved many of your personal goals, but feel there may be an aspect of your life you want to change or up-level, and 2016 is the year to do so!

Workshop Take-Aways:

·  Techniques for designing your 2016 goals and dreams, and practices to integrate them into your life.

·  Tools to move your goals into results.

·  A code to live by; supporting you and turning your dreams into reality.

This Month’s Workshop Facilitator:

Katherine Augustine (Katie) is an attorney, keynote speaker, and reverend. As a certified Life Mastery Consultant, she coaches clients throughout the nation in vision-based success techniques. Katie is also a Minister of Walking Prayer ordained by the Center for Sacred Studies. For more information on Katie, see <a>www.MagicMakerCoaching.com.</a>
results.name: Vision Your 2016 Networking Event

results.description:
The NYPL’s Community Oral History Project made it possible for communities to learn more about the origins of their neighborhoods from past and present neighbors who shared their own personal stories. These documented stories will always be available for future generations to review.

In the spirit of sharing stories, Shakespeare Saturdays would like to salute The Oral History Project and invite Shakespeare lovers to share a story about their favorite Shakespeare experience. For example, a parent might have a story about seeing their son or daughter play their first Shakespeare role. An actor might share the experience of auditioning for a respected Shakespeare Director. A teacher might share how a class responded to a Sonnet Slam. What’s your story? Please come join us for an afternoon of sharing Shakespeare.

We'll kick off this event with a song of Shakespeare text with music composed by Donna Kendall Stearns.
Featuring our Guest Singer: Josh Conway


Sat., December 19th - at 3:00 pm 

Flavorful Donations provided by Starbucks!

Inwood Branch of the New York Public Library
4790 Broadway

results.description:
Everyone, let's get in the Holiday Spirit!  Dig out your Santa hats and your Christmas sweaters, and warm up your Fa-la-la-la’s!  Come join us for the West Village Caroling Walk.

We did this last year and had a wonderful time!


It's their 43rd year strolling through the historic, Dickensian streets of the Village neighborhood singing everyone's favorite holiday songs.

After the stroll, let's come back to Judson Church for more caroling and light refreshments by the piano including hot cocoa and cookies!


Song books will be provided.  This event is FREE.


***DRESS WARM - SCARF, HAT & GLOVES RECOMMENDED and bring EYEGLASSES to read the MUSIC!

YOU CAN WEAR SANTA HATS IF YOU LIKE!



-----------------------------------------------------------------

*** The walk begins and ends at:

Judson Memorial Church

55 Washington Square South (at Thompson Street) by Washington Square Park

*** LOOK FOR US OUTSIDE ON LINE.  If we get separated when we go inside, TELL the sign in desk that you are in IVY HAMMER'S Group.


*** PLEASE BE ON TIME (3:45pm) since they are keeping our group of ladies together with a leader and we will be going out with the FIRST GROUP. 

***They will let us inside the church at 4:00pm.


***We will congregate inside by the chairs on the right side of the room before they call us to go out with a leader about 4:30pm (Maybe earlier).


*** This event starts at 4:30pm.  We will be going back to the church  around 5:30pm to warm up, grab some hot refreshments and do more caroling by the piano. 

(We may go back to the church earlier since it will be cold outside)

***You can leave the event at anytime. 


*** I will be collecting the $2.00 MEETUP FEE OUTSIDE the church PRIOR to the walk, so please have EXACT CHANGE READY.  Thank you.



PICTURES FROM LAST YEAR'S EVENT...


Subway: (Please check mta.info/weekender for service changes/advisories the day BEFORE the event)

E train to West 4th Street (upper level). Walk 5 minutes.

F train to West 4th Street (lower level). Walk 5 minutes.


R train to 8th Street/NYU.  Walk 8 minutes.

Meetup Fee:  $2.00 to help defray the cost of maintaining the group. 

EXACT CHANGE PLEASE. 


Perfume Allergy:  Please REFRAIN from wearing perfume.  Thanks for understanding.

This event should be a lot of fun.  I hope you can join us for this once a year holiday event!


Happy Holidays!

Ivy

results.description:
Today we will be focused and immersive in a  specific theme we will work on together as a group.

In today's challenge we will be drawing from Christmas themes but of course with a twist. Ever wanted to have the chance to draw a post apocalyptic Santa's sliege, Frosty the abominable Snowman, A ginger bread fortress, cheery  yet fantastically whimsical  christmas elves, or even a cybernetic Santa? Well come on down and maybe you will!

The meetup will be split into three parts: First sketches and warm-up exercises/conceptual discussion, then an hour and a half drawing your chosen idea and design, lastly we'll discuss each others drawings and ideas as a group.

So don't forget to bring your supplies and sketchbook as this meetup is going to be drawing focused!

Also if you'd like to share anything such as art or reference books with the group relating to the theme I urge you to bring them!

You can find me at the tables on the second floor of the Cranberry Cafe.

I hope to see you there and having fun participating in this new style of meetup and exercising or developing your drawing and conceptual skills with other imaginative artists throughout NYC. Any skill level and any style is welcomed!

The samba for beginners’ class starts with a 30-minute warm up that exercises basic isolation of the body, following by stretching and strengthening exercises. After the warm up, Danielle introduces the students samba no pé (basic samba step) and passo marcado (simple choreographies) typical of the Rio Carnival. The whole class happens in the sound of the upbeat and irresistible Brazilian music.

The class will be held on Saturday from 5-6:30pm and costs $18.

Come with comfortable clothes and be prepared to be barefoot.

About the instructor:

Danielle Lima was born in Rio de Janeiro and grew up performing with Beija-Flor de Nilópolis, one of Brazil’s most famous samba schools. Danielle Lima is also a Certified Teachers Artist of the program Dancing Classrooms from American Ballroom Theater, Certified YOGA Instructor at YOGA Effects in NYC and Karma Kids Yoga certified teacher.

For more information, contact Danielle Lima daniellelima13@ hotmail.com.

results.description:
Welcome!

If you love to play basketball, but height is not your advantage, come out and play with people who aren't excessively tall! In the tradition of Spud Webb, anyone under 5'8", male or female, is welcome to join us on the court. We'll get some teams together and play some competitive, but relaxed bball-- and without any giant hands in our faces! :-p

We rent out the gym from 5:00-8:00pm. Please arrive at least 5-10 minutes early as the sooner everyone arrives, the sooner we can begin playing. Note that all games stop at 7:45pm as we must be out of the gym no later than 8:00pm. (If you get there late, please only ring the bell once. It is very loud! And it takes us a few minutes to get downstairs.) The gym is on the 10th fl. & has adjoining bathrooms, lockers, and water fountains.

Don't forget:


* You must be no more than 5'8" to play!

* You must RSVP on the site in order to attend!

* To be eligible to play we ask that you sign an annual waiver, which can be found here.


* If you have any problems with the prepay, just shoot one of the organizers a message. 

The Rules:

1. Play by ones and twos to 11 - win by one point.

2. Make it - take it.

3. Backcourt if the ball hits the rim or backboard. Air balls are fair game to put right back up.

4. Jump balls/disputed calls will be determined by a three pointer since the laws of basketball physics are very clear that "the ball never lies."

5. Walls, half-court line, and ceiling are out of bounds. 

6. Usually each team has 1-2 subs. Subs should enter mid-game (one of the teams reaches 6 points) and should start the following game. Teams can regulate themselves but let's just make sure everyone plays!

See you on the court! B-)

***SPECIAL NOTES***

Please do not show up unannounced (without RSVP):

This gym is small and 22 is the maximum number of players we can realistically allow. There is a waiting list if all spots have been taken. If you do show up unannounced we will have to ask you to leave. 

Refund Policy:

A refund/credit is available if you change your RSVP at least 24 hours in advance OR, if you change your RSVP within 24 hours, as long as you post a comment on the event page and someone picks up your spot (BOTH are required).

Lastly...

Feel free to bring your own basketball for shoot-around. And don't forget to clip your fingernails prior to game day. We tried playing with Edward Scissorhands once - it didn't turn out so well.

The Afterparty: 

We'll hit up McSwiggans (393 2nd Avenue @ 23rd St) later!

results.description:
A Conversation About Happiness

Self-Moderated This Week, 12/19.  (Alternating Hosts: George & Michael Y. )

(photo of meetup table below)

CitiCorp Atrium Lower Level 


153 E 53rd street (Between Lexington and 3rd ave)

Look for our red Meetup Sign.

Get ready to get happier simply by talking about happiness! The theory behind these events comes from a classic psychology study showing that by simply talking regularly about happiness we can become much happier.

While we'll depart from them however much we may wish, like by talking about gratitude, acts of kindness, meditation and other happiness techniques, the following list of 14 topics will serve as a backdrop for our discussions.

1. Keep busy and be more active
2. Spend more time socializing
3. Be productive at meaningful work
4. Get better organized and plan things out
5. Stop worrying
6. Lower your expectations and aspirations
7. Develop positive, optimistic thinking
8. Become present oriented
9. Develop an outgoing, social personality
10. Work on a healthy personality
11. Be yourself
12. Eliminate negative feelings and problems
13. Close relationships are the number one source of happiness
14. Put happiness as your most important priority.

Here's some background on the research our group is based on.

In 1980 three New Zealand researchers found that after eight 2-hour conversation sessions about happiness over four weeks, their subjects reported a 22 percent increase in their happiness. Continuing their twice-weekly sessions, by the sixteenth week they reported being 42 percent happier.

Our list of topics comes from Fort Myers, Florida psychologist Michael Fordyce's "14 Fundamentals of Happiness." In 1977, Fordyce pioneered the science of happiness-increase with the world's first experiment designed to boost individual happiness.

That's the group. It's important that our events be fun! So with that in mind, let's get serious about ramping up our enjoyment of life!

At the NE corner of 53rd and Lex., walk down wide steps (see photo) leading to lower outdoor patio. Pass entrance to the subway station on the right, and walk through the revolving door. Walk straight about 30 yards, down a few steps; the Atrium is on the left.

Resources:

For those interested in learning about the major findings from social science research about happiness, and becoming happier, here are links to several excellent peer-reviewed articles that can be downloaded as pdf files for free. (Note: Although these classic articles are somewhat dated, decades of research on happiness reveal that findings on happiness tend to be extremely stable over time.)

Pursuing Happiness: The Architecture of Sustainable Change
By S Lyubomirsky, KM Sheldon and D Schkade, 2005.  21 pages

In Pursuit of Happiness: Empirical Answers to Philosophical Questions
By P Kesebir and E Diener, 2008. 9 pages.

Subjective Well-Being: Three Decades of Progress
By E Diener, EM Suh, RE Lucas and HL Smith, 1999. 27 pages
results.how_to_find_us: At the NE corner of 53rd and Lex., walk down wide steps leading to lower outdoor patio. Pass entrance to the subway station on the right, and walk through the revolving door. Walk straight about 30 yards, down a few steps; the Atrium is on the left.
results.name: A Conversation About Happiness (self-moderated this week) at Citicorp

results.description: There is something special about the month of December. Whether the holiday lights or decorations, the beginning of winter, the ending of another year or the love in the air and the joy in our hearts. Indeed December is a special month to all of us. Once again, Arlene and I are opening our home to our members to a wonderful evening. We will be serving, cheese & crackers with wine/soda, playing yahtzee and coffee/tea/dessert after the game. We will play yahtzee as couples and if you never played, don't worry, it won't take you 3 minutes to learn. We will be playing a quicker version, using one card per couple and variation rules. Once again we will be giving out an award to the winning couple. If there are couples who want to pass on the game and just enjoy the fun, you are more then welcome to come. A great night for laughs and a good way to get to know our members. We will tried to fit in as many couples as possible. What could you bring? Nothing is necessary, just bring your fun and holiday spirit. My house is very easy to get to by train (Ave N-(F) around the corner) and parking in the area should not be difficult. I do have a 90' driveway if you want to park there. I also have a private room in the back of my property, for anyone who wants to take a break or a smoke. This is our 6th year we have done this and indeed it is very popular. We will tried to allow more couples then last year but my home can only hold so many.We will however will be taking a waiting list and I will asked for confirmations several weeks before the event. Athough the time is for 5:00, if you get there an hour or two later is not a problem.
results.name: An Evening of Good Times, Yahtzee & Dessert 6.

results.description:
How to be unconditionally happy?

A mind that is calm, without anticipation and agitation is the birth right of all individuals. A mind that is in the present moment will be happy.


What can get you to that state?

The rest you gain by reposing in yourself is deeper than the deepest sleep. The deeper your rest, the more dynamic your activity is. By being peaceful and happy you can turn your body into a power-house by generating an inner source of energy.


Meditation is simple and is a practical way to recharge and rejuvenate; empowering you to do more of the things you love.

Come join us for free guided session and experience the power of meditation.


Workshop Contents:

- Understanding the nature of the mind!
- Relaxing Breathing Techniques
- Guided Meditation
- Introduction to the Happiness Course and Sudarshan Kriya

results.description:
Once a year, the Dyker Heights community transforms their quaint little out-of-the-way Brooklyn neighborhood into a totally intense Christmas experience. Let's check out the Dyker Heights Christmas Experience together. 

This event is open to everyone. 

To make things simple, we will meet at the base of the Washington Square Park Arch at 5 PM and get to know each other for 20 minutes. Be advised that if you show up even 1 minute late you will miss us. We will be taking the D train Dyker Heights together. It should be an awesome experience. 

How will you find us? Look for the group of people standing at the base of the Washington Square Park Arch and then look for the tallest guy there. That will be Beau, your Date Walk organizer. If you are unsure you can call Beau at[masked] and he will wave you over to where the group is. If you want to meet us in Dyker Heights instead, that's fine. Meet us at the 79th Street stop of the D line around 7p; however, it may be a nightmare trying to find each other. I would strongly advise travelling with the group.

What to expect? Date Walks are very casual and easy-to-attend / non-awkward + the host Beau is always there to make introductions. It’s really easy to meet people. 

Rain Date: If it rains this walk will be cancelled. 

When you come to the event pay $10 and I will provide you with a ticket that’s good for 30-days. Hold onto the ticket and come to any/all Date Walking events for 30 days. Just show your ticket and you're good to go. 

Why am I paying you a fee for a place I can go to for free? See the answer here. 

If you have any questions prior to or on the day of the event, please do not hesitate to give me a call.

Thank you, 
Beau, your Date Walking Organizer 

Call/Text:[masked] 
Email: [masked] 
Date Walking | Facebook­ | Twitter­

results.description:
Join the Upper West Side community for this heartwarming neighborhood event. Now in it's 25th Year, the Wonderful Christmastime Concert is an eagerly anticipated event, for the the audience, the performers and myself as producer and host. Everyone is welcome, so bring your family and friends. Artists include the West End Gospel Choir, Regina Zona opera artist & interpreter of Jake Heggie's works, Linda Bianchi, jazz artist, girl group The Janes, and Sharon Discorfano, with many surprise guests. Don't Miss It!! Suggested Contribution $5, but please give more if you can. Proceeds help West End Church Community Programs. West End Church is a More Light Presbyterian Church (www.mlp.org) I've included some links below of some of the artists. Enjoy!

Here's Linda Bianchi performing from her CD "Christmas in NY" available on Amazon.com and CDBaby.com

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xRZgaxilDdI

Here's Regina Zona in Recital singing the big aria from Cilea's Adrianna Lecouvreur.

Here's a link to THE JANES.
